I'm presuming it's another few months before we actually get to see that you've taken the business, but I also noted that you said your operations in Coles should be up and running by March and I'm just wondering how much independence the operational management and store management will have to work on these improvements until they actually get settled in?

Well. Ben, Mick and the team, Terry Bowen and the team alluding the change at the moment, actually Norman and I involved in it, but they don't waiting for Ian to arrive and we've got a lot to achieve over the next few months and Mick will be leading that and we look forward to telling you what – in the breaking down, I feel where we're at, but there will be a lot we get done over the next couple of months. Ian was always going to arrive in May.

Okay and my last question is for Gene, actually and I'm just wondering what your expectations are for debt markets over the next six months, both here and offshore, particularly given recent debt rolls, it seems like they are like a and alike?

Yeah. Well, our expectations are that we'll get the kinds of rates that are investment grade as corporate does on fairly large amounts of debt as to just where markets will go, there are some signs that liquidity is improving, but we've seen a lot of turbulence and a lot of surprises. So I'm not giving any forecast on that the overall debt market.
Thank you. The next question is from Shaun Cousins of JPMorgan. Please go ahead, Shaun.

Hi, guys. Just regarding the fair value adjustment to the provision relating to the Coles acquisition, I think it increased by 390 million. By what time will you release this provision and what does this provision relate to?

The provision adjustments came about in a number of areas. There was some right-back company profits, some adjustments on software and some other contracts, so some of those will amortize over a few years and some will run out probably five plus years.
Sorry, doesn't demand as you release distribution doesn't exactly support your earnings growth in the coming years?
Well, the release of provisions, the provisions that I can get relief they get paid out by the time.
Okay. So, you just get a better paid off what's related to cash?
Yes, for some time, but the effect reduces over time as those are amortized.
And we should be watching that effect if we have that adjustment to your provision line moves just to see how this release comes through, okay?
Yes. I think over time you'll find its pretty small in the scheme of things.
But it will certainly help your earnings.
Yes.
Okay. And just the restructuring one-offs that you're talking about coming up in the second half '08; are they in addition or are they related to this provision?
There will be additional structuring one-offs in the second half.
And are they in addition to the increase that -- the provision that you've taken?
Yes, they are.
I guess. Well -- all right. Thanks.
Thank you. The next question is from Martin Yuel of Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead, Martin.

Yes, a question for Richard. I guess one of your jobs in the last couple of months has been having some conversations with coal suppliers. So, I was wondering if you would comment on your observations and whether you sort of perceive a margin difference between yourselves and Woolworth's based on supplier costs?

I wouldn't comment on that. All I'd say is that the conversations I've had with suppliers have been that they're very supportive of what we try to do with the business and want to be engaged and assist us. But as I said that to all our competitors, but, well, we really look forward to having a very positive engagement with suppliers where they can help us in getting things in our stores more efficiently and provide a better offer for our customers; we'll work very closely with them. And you know, we know they're a very important part of the business and we'll be treating them with that respect.

Just intuitively you'd think that, you know that would look at you taking over and think that this is a great opportunity to sort of restore some of the imbalance. Are you getting any positive commentary like that or is it just a case of you're just another corporate that they deal with?

To the extent have been very positive at the moment, because they really want us to succeed, I think. They probably do want some balance. But you know, sort of, we all know suppliers are also in business for their own purposes.
And you don't want to comment on the prices that you can see this is what your market intelligence tells you that worth its getting?
Not at this date.
Okay, thanks.
Thank you. The next question is from Sundu Benson of BT Financial Group. .

Yes, I've just got a question on the retail performance. And I know it's not clear but it seems that things are going quite well. I'm just a bit confused now about comments made around the cash flow and there being some kind of inventory issue that needed to be resolved. Can you just comment on that, whether that -- you know, there's any inventory excess, or are you short on inventory and need to make investment?

The issue really was a timing issue. If you think about the date we acquired Coles, which is the 23 of November, then there's a build-up of inventory for Christmas trading. And so we've got big cash flow, strong cash flow generation from those Coles businesses through that trading period. That's really what Gene is referring to it. So it was really timing. We picked the business up when there was a significant investment in inventory, and some of that was realized through the Christmas trading period, and that's generate cash.
Okay. So, there's no inventory issues, is it, December 31? So we shouldn't expect any inventory write-down?
Well, we're having a good look at all of that, but nothing of great magnitude.
I think the inventory's related to the businesses that are within their typical vein.
Okay. Great, thanks.
Thank you. The next question is from David Whittaker of Southern Cross.

Okay, guys, outstanding results; John Gillam from Donahue. If you keep this up, you're going to may look like a bear. So, I'm just wondering whether, if given the way the trade seems to be going, you're very optimistic on that. If the trade through plannings stipe materializes, is it possible that we could be looking at better than 11% within that business?

Thanks, David. Look, we're very cautious about the net EBIT margin at the trading of that margin, and grow it through greatly. We're students of the productivity, and we're driving more volumes, and hence, strong earnings growth through rewarding customers with better value. So we do looks to reward our customers with lower cost, in fact. And we know that on our price baskets, on our basket of goods, we're not contributing to inflation, we've had deflation in selling prices, so on our gross margin, they're all back up in our P&L. As we look at the long-term, we see gross margins decline.
Okay. And just on the trade improvements, what are the key strategies that you're saying having an effect there?

Well, what we've done is take a very hard look at how best to look after the different types of trade customers. So we've developed our model for large delivered to site customers, and we're servicing them through trade PC, and we trying to get some good traction from these trade centers. And in our stores, where pickup is clearly attractive, and traders can take benefit of whatever they're working, we've got someone to help. And we're also working hard to pick up, what we do at that end of the store, and that's going to reward to provide some traction for us.
Okay. Thanks very much, and good one, guys.
Thanks, Dave.
Thank you, the next question is from Matthew McNee of Goldman Sachs JBWere. Please go ahead, Matthew.
Thank you...
I think we've got time for about two more questions, or something. People are going to race offside, sorry.

Right. This is just a quick one; just on the updated current hedging profile, obviously, you have an assumption about the long-term price beyond this year. Can you just remind us whether that's changed, what it is at the moment, just to make more sense of those numbers?

Well, I suppose the long-term view on coal prices is a little bit problematic at the moment when the coal prices set for this year. And once we accept those prices, we will be able to increase the hedging, particularly in the short term. So, we don't normally give our long-term estimates of coal prices or where that's heading.
Now it's just for us to make any sense of this 68% hedge we need to know what that number is. Otherwise it's not of any use.

So, Matthew you can assume that those percentages are based on a pretty conservative outlook for coal prices, and that we, since those figures were put out we are continuing the hedging program, and we will be hedging as the prices firm.
All right, no worries. Thank you very much.

So Matthew, just to help you a bit more, I mean a few years ago we were quickly reverting to the long-run average price for coke and coal, that we've moved that up a bit. But it's in tens of dollars, not, no a great amount over the last couple of years.
Thank you. Your final question is from Grant Saligari of Commonwealth Securities. Please go ahead, Grant.
Just a follow-up. Your dividend reinvestment plan you've underwritten for 75% for the first half dividend. Any plan to continue that underwriting?
Well, it's quite possible that we will continue to underwrite, but we'll make those decisions as we progress depending on other capital initiatives and requirements of the Group.
And do you, it look -- are you of the view that you need to raise more equity and reduce your debt load over the next two or three years?
We're looking, as we've indicated we're looking at hybrids and the like, which require the equity.
Would you rule out a equity raising?
We're going to keep them rule anything out because we don't know what opportunities will come along and how markets will change.
Okay, thanks.
Well, thank you all very much for joining us and we look forward to catching up soon. Thanks.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for you participation in today's conference. This does conclude the conference and you may now disconnect. Thank you.
